I.  THE PROPOSAL   
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of Indonesia for the Power Transmission Improvement (PTI) Sector Project.  
 
2.  At the request of the Government of Indonesia, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
approved  a  project  preparation  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  the  power  transmission 
improvement project.1 The project proposal was included in the Country Assistance Plan (2001-
2003) and it is now titled the PTI Sector Project. The sector project framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES  
A.  Power Sector Overview    
3.  The formulation of power sector development policies is the responsibility of the Ministry 
of Energy and Mineral Resources, which discharges its control and regulatory functions through 
the  Directorate  General  for  Electricity  and  Energy  Utilization  (DGEEU).  State  Electricity 
Enterprise (PLN) is responsible for developing and operating the power sector and serves over 
30 million consumers. The Ministry for State-Owned Enterprises exercises sole shareholder's 
powers on behalf of the Government. PLN's total installed power generation capacity reached 
21,000 megawatts (MW) in December 2001. PLN’s operational assets also include 24,800 
circuit-kilometers  (cct-km)  of  transmission  lines;  substation  capacity  of  50,000  megavolt-
amperes (MVA); and medium- and low-voltage lines totaling 287,500 cct-km. The Java-Bali 
power grid has 74% of the installed capacity, with the rest spread over 1,100 power grids. 
 
4.  PLN's installed power generation capacity outside Java-Bali (the outer islands) is only 
5,270  MW  (2000),  and the total energy sale, 16.7 terawatt-hour (TWh) (2000). The area's 
geographical features (islands and inhabited forests) have fragmented the power grid into small 
separate grids, some with less than 10 MW capacity. Economies of scale are possible, and as 
power demand grows, the grids must interconnect. Increasing the size of the power grids allows 
operation of larger and more efficient power generation units. The south, central, and west 
Sumatra power grids are being interconnected under an ongoing ADB loan.2  The power grid of 
East Kalimantan has a capacity of 140 MW, and South Kalimantan, 340 MW; over 62% of 
energy production is diesel-based. The interconnection of the two grids will help optimize 
operations, improve the reliability of power supply, and facilitate the transfer of 60 MW power 
from East to South Kalimantan instead of building a new power plant. 
  
5.  Electricity is also generated by power plants with an aggregate capacity of about 12,000 
MW. Large industries and businesses own and operate the plants, and PLN customers own 
about half of these captive power plants, allowing these electricity users to buy power from PLN 
or generate their own. Since the plants are unregulated, sufficient data is not available to 
determine the actual amount of electricity used, or the impact of tariffs on PLN’s power demand. 
Independent power producers (IPPs), which are under contract to sell all their power output to 
PLN, have the capacity to generate another 3,000 MW.

6.  PLN's  power  supply  extends  to  49,000  (84%)  of  58,000  villages,  and  53%  of  the 
estimated 52 million households are PLN’s customers. The reliability of power supply has 
generally been better than in many other developing member countries (DMCs), and Java-Bali 
has not experienced a system-wide power failure in the past 5 years despite PLN’s financial 
problems. Industrial and commercial customers find the electricity tariff competitive. Reduction 
of  the  subsidy  on  liquid  fuels3  will  increase  the  cost  of  self-generation  and  improve  the 
competitiveness of PLN's supply. 
 
7.  During 1998-2002, the capacity factor increased by about 3%, which indicates that the 
existing power stations are generating more energy. The load factor has remained in the 67.5–
69.5% range, indicating that the growth in peak power demand has been normal. The tariff 
structure for large consumers includes a multiplier to reflect a higher supply during evening 
hours. PLN has also introduced measures that allow it to negotiate lower tariffs to encourage 
demand-side management. Although the average electricity tariff has risen significantly in recent 
years, it still remains lower than alternate options, and so energy sales have not been affected 
much.  
 
B.  Power Sector Development Plan 
8.  Until 1997, DGEEU and PLN regularly prepared power sector development plans to 
reflect an annual energy sales growth rate of about 12%, and resources were mobilized to 
implement these plans. Although the plans were optimistic, PLN could acquire resources to 
implement new  projects. In 1997, about 70% surplus generation capacity was available and 
several new power generation projects were under implementation, some by IPPs. The crisis 
had two significant impacts: (i) the growth of energy sales slowed, reducing the urgency to add 
new power generation capacity; and (ii) the electricity tariffs could only be gradually raised to 
reflect increased cost of electricity supply, so financial performance results of PLN were poor 
and  it  could  not  borrow  for  capital  investment.  These  factors  introduced  considerable 
uncertainties in the power sector planning process, and available resources barely allowed PLN 
to complete ongoing projects.  
 
9.  The situation has gradually changed. The annual energy sales growth is now about 
10%, and although the economic forecasts still lack clarity, PLN has prepared power demand 
projections  corresponding  to  annual  economic  growth  of  3.5–6.0%  and  an  increase  in 
electrification ratio4 from 53% to 75% by 2010. A summary of the power development plan, i.e., 
the forecast of demand growth and capacity additions required in the power sector, is in 
Appendix 2. The electricity tariff was gradually raised during 2000–2002, and the Government 
plans to keep raising it to a level of full cost recovery and a reasonable rate of return by 2005. 
The projected higher electricity sales revenue will allow PLN to meet the operating costs 
(including power purchase from IPPs) and borrow funds for the new investment required to 
satisfy power demand growth. A delay in new investment will reduce the reliability of PLN’s 
power supply, and the Java-Bali power grid could have a power shortfall by 2005. To address 
such concerns, large consumers may decide to implement new captive power plants, which 
would be a less efficient and environment-friendly outcome.

C.  Power Sector Policies    
10.  Based on the Government’s Power Sector Restructuring Policy (August 1998), ADB 
approved a policy-based program loan (the Program) and the associated capacity-building loan 
(TA Loan).5 The Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC) also approved a loan of $400 
million, disbursed in two equal tranches, and linked to the release of the two program loan 
tranches. The first program loan tranche of $200 million was disbursed in March 1999 and the 
Board's approval is being sought for the release of the second tranche following the enactment 
and promulgation of the Electricity Law 20 on 23 September 2002.6 
 
11.  The Program seeks to make the power sector more efficient and financially viable by 
establishing a competitive electricity market in Java-Bali. The new electricity law provides the 
necessary legal framework. The law allows ventures to obtain licenses for different functions: 
generation, transmission, distribution, sales (only for low-voltage consumers), sales agency (for 
high-  and  medium-voltage  consumers  and  may  include  low-voltage  consumers),  market 
operation,  and  system  operation.  The  various  ventures  will  be  undertaken  separately  by 
different enterprises, which will prevent reintegration and limit the market power of participants. 
The electricity generation ventures will be subject to competition and are specifically prohibited 
from acquiring market dominance. The transmission and distribution ventures will be recognized 
as natural monopolies, but will be required to provide open access with tariff regulated by the 
power market supervisory agency (the regulatory body) that will be established within 1 year. 
Electricity supply ventures and supply agencies will buy electricity from the electricity market or 
through bilateral contracts and sell to consumers. The market organizer will determine electricity 
market prices and the system operator will match supply and demand according to market rules 
set by the regulatory body. The market organizer and system operator will be accountable and 
impartial  to,  and  financed  by  charges  paid  by,  the  market  participants.  The  transmission 
venture, market operation, and system operation will first be integrated and later separated as 
business activities grow. The new electricity law also stipulates that the electricity sales price for 
generation and for medium- and high-voltage consumers will be based on natural and sound 
competition.  Based  on  the  consensus  reached  in  the  House  of  Representatives  (DPR), 
competition will start in power generation within 5 years. Based on the progress made during 
this period, the electricity law will allow the regulatory body to extend licenses to interested sales 
agents. These agents can also start buying electricity form the market once it is established and 
sell to some medium- and high-voltage consumers on a competitive basis. In the absence of 
sales agents, however, the regulatory body will set the electricity price for all the consumers.

13.  To  facilitate  the  transition  to  an  unbundled  power  sector,  the  focus  now  is  on 
decentralization and empowerment of operational units by making them strategic business units 
(SBUs). The corporate office, which earlier made all decisions in operational and investment-

subsidiaries. During the past 2 years, many corporate staff have been relocated to SBUs. SBU 
general managers now exercise full responsibility for energy sales, including the expansion of 
the distribution network. The larger generation and transmission projects are implemented 
under the direct control of the corporate office. However, in the next phase of decentralization, 
SBU  managers  will  share  responsibility  for  procurement  and  be  fully  responsible  for  the 
implementation of all the projects in their respective regions. SBUs will eventually have the 
flexibility to negotiate agreements for power purchase at the local level based on projected 
energy  sale  and  revenue.  With  the  strengthening  of  managerial  capacity,  SBUs  are  well 
positioned to coordinate the development and management of the regional power sector with 
the provincial and regency governments. When local governments establish their financial 
capacity to invest in regional development and are prepared to adjust the regional electricity 
tariffs to reflect the full cost of the power supply in the region, SBUs are envisaged to be 
separated from PLN as jointly owned subsidiaries. The new electricity law allows such vertically 
integrated power companies in the outer islands to be owned by the private sector. Like any 
network industry, economies of scale are available in the power sector. While administrative 
decentralization may transfer authority to nearly 400 regencies and cities, fragmentation of the 
power sector is not advisable.  
   
14.  PLN  has  adopted  another  three  programs  to  directly  benefit  the  poor  and  small

helped create 29,000 jobs for villagers; (ii) the rural electrification loan, which provides low-
interest loans to poor households unable to pay the new connection charge (about Rp60 billion 
to 781,000 consumers); and (iii) the program to empower small businesses and cooperatives, 
which extends loans for working capital, and grants for training, quality improvement, and

and Rp34 billion as pledges—to over 43,000 units). With its improved financial results, PLN 
allocated Rp13 billion to the scheme in 2002 and 2003.

16.  A  detailed  analysis  of  PLN  financial  performance  is  in  Appendix  3.  The  main 
components  of  operating  costs  are  power  purchase,  fuel  and  lubricants,  maintenance, 
personnel, and depreciation. The trend for these and other important operational parameters is 
better than that in other DMC utilities, particularly the low energy losses (11.5–13.5%) and

crisis is now higher and, based on the policy of the early 1990s, PLN now buys more power 
from IPPs instead of investing in new power generation capacity.8 It avoided incurring larger 
debt to build about 3,000 MW of new capacity. 
 
17.  PLN has pursued an efficiency improvement program based on an operational and 
capital expenditure audit carried out by international experts in 1999. All units were assigned 
loss reduction targets, which involved several actions such as reduction of fuel consumption, 
inventory levels, maintenance costs, and the billing cycle. Steps were also taken for customer 
voltage improvement, load balancing, and efficient procurement of spares and consumables. 
PLN estimates that the resultant savings in 2001 were Rp1 trillion. 
 
18.  Under the 1985 electricity law, the Government sets the electricity tariff for various 
consumer categories to allow PLN to recover all its costs. While this had not been particularly 
difficult until 1997, the Government has faced a challenge since then in raising tariffs to adjust 
for  the  higher  costs.  Wider  support  and  greater  transparency  are  now  needed,  including 
discussions in the DPR. A sharp increase in electricity tariff would be inflationary, reduce 
domestic  savings,  and  thus  slow  economic  recovery.  Despite  the  difficulties,  the  average 
revenue from electricity sales has increased from Rp211 per kilowatt-hour (kWh) in 1999 (when 
ADB appraised the Program loan) to Rp437/kWh in June 2002. To offset a lower tariff for small 
households (decided by DPR), a subsidy of Rp6.7 trillion covering a period of 3 years was 
transferred to PLN in 2001.  
 
19.  Another correction remains for PLN to incorporate in its balance sheet. The net asset

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Objectives and Scope 
28.  The Project will (i) remove power supply bottlenecks in selected power substations and 
medium-voltage transmission lines in Java-Bali, (ii) interconnect outer-island power grids, and 
(iii) provide information and communication technology (ICT)-based equipment for a competitive 
electricity market and consulting services to supervise its installation. 
 
29.  The Java-Bali power grid subprojects will add power transformers (360 MW), switchyard 
bays (37), indoor switchgear feeders (48), 150 kV transmission lines (upgrading 113 km and 
constructing  129  km),  and  capacitors  (120  megavolt-ampere-reactive  [MVAr])  to  remove 
bottlenecks in power supply to major load centers with increasing power demand, which are in 
Jakarta, Serang in West Java, Bandung and Semarang in Central Java, and Malang in East 
Java.  The  augmentation  of  substation  capacity  will  avoid  adverse  impacts  from  power 
interruption caused by substation overload, or low voltage supply. The installed capacity of the 
power  grid  in  East  Kalimantan  is  140  MW,  and  in  South  Kalimantan,  340  MW.  The

interconnection with the 276 km transmission line will help realize economies of scale, provide 
operational flexibility, and maximize the use of resources.  
 
30.  The ICT component will include the information technology (IT) system needed to 
operate the competitive electricity market. Once the Java-Bali electricity market is operational, 
the power sector will be deregulated (retail price and entry will be depend on supply and 
demand), thus allowing access to the private sector without government guarantees. The 
market rules have been developed and a suitable financial settlement system is being prepared 
under the ADB-funded TA loan (footnote 5). An international consultant is also being selected 
under another component of the TA Loan to prepare the specifications for the computer 
software and hardware of the IT system, which will be used to procure the goods and services 
under the Project’s ICT component.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Economic and Financial Analyses 
1.  Least-Cost Option    
56.  A least cost analysis was carried out by comparing the costs related to the envisaged 
subprojects and alternate diesel-based power plants. The proposed strengthening of the Java-
Bali power grid and interconnection of power grids in Kalimantan are considered the least-cost 
option to develop efficient and reliable transmission in the subproject areas.  
 
2.  Economic Evaluation 
57.  The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  was  calculated  for  the  transmission 
subprojects and the ICT-based equipment for the competitive electricity market (Appendix 7). 
The EIRR was determined by valuing costs and benefits in economic terms. Domestic prices in 
constant 2002 value were used in economic evaluation. Capital and O&M costs were adjusted 
to remove taxes, duties, and other transfer payments. Local currency expenditures relating 
mostly to nontraded goods are equal to their domestic value, and a shadow exchange rate of

15
1.05 was applied to calculate the economic prices of traded goods from their financial prices 
(based on a standard conversion factor of 0.95). Incremental energy available for sale is valued 
in terms of consumer willingness to pay. 
 
58.  The EIRR for the subprojects in the Java-Bali power grids and the competitive electricity 
market was estimated at 33.2%, and for the interconnection of power grids at 22.5%. The 
investments are thus economically viable and the resulting benefits sufficiently high to justify the 
costs incurred by the subprojects, including capital costs. The EIRR calculation was subject to 
sensitivity analysis to test the effect of possible unfavorable changes in key variables. 
 
3.  Financial Analysis 
59.  The financial analysis of the core subprojects of the Project was carried out based on 
real terms using constant 2002 prices. The financial evaluation assumes that tariffs will be set to 
achieve the full cost recovery and adequate rate of return. The annual energy flows through the 
transmission system subprojects have been forecast based on the results of network analysis. 
The costs include capital investment, fuel, O&M, and those for the associated distribution 
system.  Revenues  in  the  financial  analysis  were  valued  at  the  average  tariff,  which  was 
calculated  based  on  the  weighted  average  of  tariffs  for  all  the  customer  groups  (social,

4.  Project Beneficiaries 
60.  The Project is justified. The subprojects in the Java-Bali power grid will help remove 
transmission bottlenecks and ensure efficient and reliable power supply. Electricity is in demand 
not only among rich and middle-income consumers but also among the poor who require 
electricity to meet their basic needs. Electricity is vital to create jobs, support most economic 
activities, and thus reduce poverty. The Project will help remove supply bottlenecks in Java-Bali 
and integrate medium-sized power grids in the outer islands to help achieve economies of 
scale. The Project will also develop electricity market facilities to establish and operate the 
power generation market in Java-Bali. The Project will help boost economic productivity in the 
subproject  areas  by  enhancing  energy  efficiency  and  reliability  of  power  supply.  Existing 
industrial and commercial consumers (including small and medium-sized enterprises) will be 
able to continue their operations, and some new units will be connected because of the 
increased substation capacity. The labor force, which includes the poor working in the informal 
sectors, will be assured of continued employment. 
 
61.  ICT-based systems for the competitive electricity market in Java-Bali are essential for 
the  ongoing  power  sector  restructuring  program.  Competition  in  power  generation  will 
encourage efficiency among electricity producers and other power companies, lower the bulk 
electricity price and bring it closer to the marginal cost, and thus force down the average retail 
electricity price and directly benefit all households connected to the power grid, including the 
poor.

accruing to the poor was estimated at Rp1 trillion during the Project, including the economic

share of consumer surplus for the poor reflects the proportion of poor households with PLN

C.  Risks 
68.  No significant technical risks are associated with the proposed investment. The Project 
is  considered  financially  and  economically  sound  and  capable  of  withstanding  reasonable 
changes in major parameters. Institutional risks are not considered significant as PLN has a 
comprehensive organizational structure in the outer islands. However, the success of the 
Project depends on (i) the Government's approval for revaluing PLN’s assets, and a gradual 
increase of electricity tariff from 2003; (ii) decentralization of PLN and empowerment of SBUs; 
and (iii) timely preparation of required documents for subproject approval, efficient procurement, 
and project implementation. The Government has assured ADB that PLN's assets will be 
revalued and the tariff increased on time.  PLN has approved the establishment of support 
functions for SBUs. The last condition for success will be minimized through close monitoring 
and ADB review missions. The Project is in the infrastructure sector with revenue in the 
domestic currency, exposing the investment to the foreign exchange rate. The ongoing reforms 
aim at macroeconomic stabilization. Over the long run, the restructuring of the power sector will 
allow managing the price risk through the competitive electricity market. Until this is possible, 
the Government will gradually raise the electricity tariff to an appropriate level and reintroduce 
an automatic tariff adjustment mechanism to maintain financial viability. 
 
69.  The timely and successful implementation of the competitive electricity market is subject 
to the ongoing power sector reorganization, under which generation, distribution, supply, and 
transmission will be separated into independent businesses. The Government must maintain its 
commitment to the restructuring and implementation schedule. Although competitive electricity 
markets operate successfully in several countries, international experience underscores the 
risks related to market dominance and limitation on bilateral contracts. The design of the 
competitive electricity market in Indonesia takes into account these factors and the specific 
features of the Java-Bali power system. The new electricity law requires competition in power 
generation to start in 5 years. Provisions have also been made for retail competition but a 
timetable has not been specified to allow for a gradual evolution of the competitive market 
without raising concerns among the stakeholders, particularly civil society. The Government 
also confirmed that the regulatory body will be established within 1  year in line with the 
electricity law to ensure timely operation of the competitive market and an independent tariff

H.  Planning Constraints 
14.  The higher foreign exchange rate since 1997 has increased PLN’s costs, mainly to

started in 1999, PLN estimates that it has saved about $60 million in operational expenditure.

derated power plants, which provided larger benefits and required less time to implement than 
adding new power generating capacity. The program includes the following:

(ii)  efficiency improvement of Muara Karang steam gas-based units 4 and 5 (2 x 200

Development Organization of Japan; and

Cooperation Agency. 
 
17.  Excess Power from Captive Power Plants. PLN is investigating the possibility of 
cooperating with owners of captive power plants to help meet power requirements during high-
demand evenings. Based on a December 2001 survey, about 200 MW capacity may be 
available from such power plants in Java in 2002.  
 
18.  Demand-Side Management. PLN will launch a demand-side management program in 
close cooperation with customers on voluntary basis. It will include electricity price adjustment

4.  The economic analysis was conducted using domestic market prices. The economic

1.053 (based on the standard conversion factor of 0.95) was applied to calculate the economic 
price of traded goods. Due to local labor market conditions, an unskilled labor conversion factor 
of 0.75 in domestic prices was considered. Based on these assumptions, the main costs and

C.  Costs 
5.  The  main  project  costs  cover  civil  works,  equipment,  incremental  operation  and 
maintenance, land acquisition, and resettlement with and without the Project. The economic 
costs were estimated from financial costs, including physical contingencies. Price escalation,

D.  Benefits 
6.  Enhanced Java-Bali power transmission systems and a wholesale electricity market will 
introduce competition in power supply to bring electricity prices closer to marginal costs, force 
down overall average electricity prices, and thereby increase consumption. These benefits 
accrue to incremental energy consumption and are valued at consumer willingness to pay. In 
the long term, the electricity retail prices are expected to go down about $0.02 per kilowatt-hour 
(kWh) equivalent under the Project. The literature indicates price elasticity of about  –0.3 to 
measure the economic benefits from incremental electricity consumption, which suggests that 
with  the  price  decrease  by  about  $0.02/kWh  equivalent,  market  demand  for  incremental 
electricity consumption may go up to about 20%.  
 
7.  Interconnection of power transmission systems on the outer islands will help boost 
economic productivity of the project areas. The Project viability is based on the economic 
internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR).  Average  consumer  willingness-to-pay  in  East  and  South 
Kalimantan was estimated as Rp1,251 (about $0.14/kWh equivalent) based on the willingness-
to-pay for residential, commercial, and industrial sectors, as well as their respective shares in 
consumption of power. The economic benefits were valued by applying the average consumer 
willingness-to-pay to net energy sold to consumers due to the enhanced efficiency of power 
transmission systems in the project areas. 
 
8.  The Project holds other benefits that are not easily quantified. Power transmission 
system improvement in Java-Bali and power grid interconnection on the outer islands will 
enhance  transmission  facilities,  meet  future  demand,  and  promote  balanced  regional 
development. A wholesale electricity market and competition in the generation sector through a 
system  of  marginal  cost  pricing  will  fend  off  inefficiency  in  production  (generation)  and 
consumption (distribution and large industrial customers). With the wholesale electricity supply 
market in place, the power facilities will have to compete on the basis of least cost. Generation 
facilities will be forced to keep down their operating costs, otherwise they run the risk of not 
being dispatched and being priced out of the system by more efficiently run facilities. Power 
facilities will thus be pressured to minimize their operating costs and, at the same time, become 
more efficient to improve their heat rates. 
 
E.  Results of Economic Analysis 
9.  The Project benefits will accrue to all energy consumers in the power transmission 
systems, including the residential, commercial, and industrial sectors. The Project will enhance 
power supply quality and ensure sufficient, reliable, and stable supply of power to consumers, 
including the poor. A wholesale electricity market and competition in generation are envisioned 
to bring electricity prices closer to marginal cost and force down overall average electricity 
prices. In the long run, sizable welfare gains will accrue to households, producers, and the 
economy as a whole.

B.  Capital Costs and Financial Benefits 
2.  The main project costs include capital investment,  and operation  and  maintenance

transmission lines, transformers, capacitors, switch gears, and telecommunication equipment. 
The cost for land acquisition, resettlement,  buildings, and access roads are also included. 
Market facility costs are computer hardware and software. The annual capital expenditures are 
based on the investment program of the State Electricity Enterprise (PLN). All capital costs are 
expressed in real terms using constant 2002 prices. The financial internal rate of return (FIRR) 
was calculated on the basis of the base costs, excluding price contingency and interest during 
construction. No residual value of the project was considered. 
 
3.  The  financial  benefits  for  the  Java-Bali  power  subprojects  were  measured  by  the

East to the South Kalimantan system. The forecasted power demand and subproject’s utilization 
factor  were  also  taken  into  account.  The  financial  benefits  for  the  market  facilities  were 
measured by the net cash flow, which was the net revenue generated from the system, and 
market operation, and deducting the capital and operation costs for establishment and operation 
of the market facilities.  The revenue was computed from the system and market operation fee 
per kilowatt-hour (kWh) multiplied by the volume of energy traded through the market.  All 
benefits are expressed in real terms using constant 2002 prices.

REPORT OF SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  The Power Transmission Improvement Sector Project (the Project) is an environment B 
project. It includes subprojects that will add 360 megavolt amperes (MVA) of transformation 
capacity to the Java-Bali power sector, and 276 kilometers (km) of 150 kilovolt (kV) transmission 
line to interconnect power grids in outer islands. An initial environmental examination (IEE) was 
prepared  for  the  core  subproject  in  accordance  with  the  Environmental  Assessment 
Requirements of the Asian Development Bank. This sample summary IEE (SIEE) includes 
major findings and conclusions on the 150 kv Barikin-Tanjung transmission line (58 km) in 
Kalimantan and was prepared for analytical purposes to show the nature of the Project, its likely 
potential impacts, and mitigation measures needed. 
 
B.  Description of the Core Subproject 
2.  The 58 km Barikin-Tanjung transmission line is in South Kalimantan Province, starting in 
Barikin Substation at Tower T-321 and proceeding northeast to T-530 at Tanjung Substation. 
Most of the land traversed by the line’s right-of-way corridor is used for dry rice fields (40.14%), 
underbrush (17.93%), orchards (7.77%), and other uses. In general, the dry rice fields are used 
to cultivate seasonal crops such as rice, corn, and several kind of fruits and vegetables, while 
the orchards or market gardens are occupied by annual cropping plants such as rubber, palm 
oil, coconut, durian, and others. 
 
3.  The Project is to proceed in three phases: preconstruction, construction, and operation. 
During  preconstruction,  the  main  activities  will  be  surveying,  site  investigation,  and  land 
acquisition  for  the  209  tower  sites  and  the  substations  in  Barikin  and  Tanjung.  During 
construction, the activities will be mobilization of work crews, construction of tower foundations, 
tower erection, and stringing. 
 
C.  Description of the Environment 
4.  With  the  exception  of  the  Meratus  Mountains  in  the  southeast  of  the  island,  and 
limestone outcrops in the west (the highest, Mount Mulul, is 2,377 meters [m]), much of 
Kalimantan’s land area is barely above sea level. Kalimantan's monsoon climate brings dry 
winds from the southeast from May to September; and moisture-laden winds from the northwest 
from October to March. Most rain falls from November to January, whereas July to September 
remain dry.  
5.  Compared to other regions, Kalimantan still has a low level of industrialization. Its basic 
infrastructure—community services, health provision, piped water, and education—is limited. 
The poverty level is also high, associated with low incomes, subsistence agriculture such as rice 
farming, smallholding rubber and coconut cultivation, and artisanal fishing. 
 
6.  The economy of Kalimantan is based on exploitation of its rich natural resources. Apart 
from gold and diamond mining, large-scale coal mining began in the late 19th century, followed 
by a series of oil booms. East Kalimantan has produced oil since the beginning of the 20th 
century, and liquefied natural gas is an important export. Kalimantan’s forests also provide 
valuable timber; large-scale lumber operations, which began in 1967, continue today at alarming 
rates.

7.  The  Barikin-Tanjung  transmission  line  will  result  in  limited  negative  impacts  during

owners are to be cleared. Affected owners will be compensated for the vegetation cleared. The

8.  During  the  operational  stage,  electric  and  magnetic  fields  will  result  from  power 
transmission.  Based  on  PLN  consultation  research,  the  average  electric  and  magnetic 
inductions that resulted from the Java 150 kV transmission line are 193.4 volt per meter (V/m) 
and 2.0 micro-Tesla, respectively.  These values are below the World Health Organization 
(WHO) threshold values: 5,000 V/m for the electrical field and 100 micro-Tesla for magnetic field 
as recommended in WHO Publication No. 10 on nonionizing radiation protection for safety 
threshold value for humans. Further, the ministerial decree of the minister of mines and energy 
No. 01.P/47MPE/1992 stipulates minimum clearance between a conductor and ground for 150 
kV transmission lines to minimize the potential public health hazard of a transmission line.
